'''''Pleurocybella porrigens''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the [[Marasmiaceae]] family. The species is widespread in [[temperate]] forests of the [[Northern Hemisphere]].<ref name=Kirk2008/>  ''P. porrigens'', known as the '''angel wing''', is a white-rot [[wood-decay fungus]] on [[conifer]] wood, particularly hemlock (genus ''[[Tsuga]]'').<ref name=amm09/>  The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thin and fragile compared to the oyster mushrooms (''[[Pleurotus]]'' ssp.).

''Pleurocybella porrigens'' has historically been generally regarded as [[edible mushroom|edible]]<ref name=amm09/><ref name=arora86/> but this has been brought into question by recent deaths apparently associated with ''P. porrigens'' consumption.

Synonyms for ''Pleurocybella porrigens'' include ''[[Pleurotus]] porrigens'', ''Phyllotus porrigens'', ''Dendrosarcus porrigens'', ''Pleurotellus porrigens'', and ''[[Nothopanus]] porrigens''.

== Description ==
The mushroom species is distinguished by its fruit bodies, which begin as a pure white and then form a tinge of yellow over time. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is either very short or completely absent, and the flesh has a faint but pleasant smell.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/816030405|title=The pocket guide to wild mushrooms : helpful tips for mushrooming in the field|last=Holmberg, Pelle.|date=2013|publisher=Skyhorse|others=Marklund, Hans, 1937-, Hedström, Ellen.|isbn=9781620877319|location=New York|oclc=816030405}}</ref>

==Toxicity==
[[File:Angel_wing_mushroom_(Pleurocybella_porrigens).jpg|thumb|left|210px|''Angel wing'' growing on a decaying log in Dundreggan, [[Scotland]].]]
Although ''P. porrigens'' is generally regarded as [[edible mushroom|edible]],<ref name=amm09/><ref name=arora86/> as of 2011, it has been implicated in two documented outbreaks involving fatal [[encephalopathy]].  Both incidents were in Japan, and most victims had pre-existing [[kidney]] disorders.<ref name=beugpleuro/><ref name=sav06/><ref name=gej05/> 

The first incident occurred in September and October 2004<ref name=kato2004/> across nine prefectures in Japan, and involved the sickening of 59 people and the eventual death of 17.<ref name=beugpleuro/>  Most of those who died had pre-existing liver problems, and the average age of those affected was 70.<ref name=beugpleuro/>  Death occurred between 13 and 29 days after the onset of symptoms, and the onset of symptoms occurred at most three weeks after consumption of ''P. porrigens''.<ref name=kato2004/>

The second incident occurred in 2009, when a 65-year-old man who had been on [[hemodialysis]] died from acute encephalopathy after eating ''P. porrigens''.<ref name=beugpleuro/>

The mechanism of action for the toxicity of ''P. porrigens'' has not been definitively established,<ref name=beugpleuro/> but several possibilities have been suggested.  It has been demonstrated that ''P. porrigens'' contains an unusual unstable [[amino acid]] which is toxic to the brain cells of rats in cell culture studies,<ref name=beugpleuro/><ref name=acie/> but it has not yet been possible to definitively determine that this was the cause of the fatal encephalopathies.<ref name=beugpleuro/>  Other mechanisms have been suggested for ''P. porrigens'''s apparent toxicity, including the possibility that the fungus may contain toxic levels of [[cyanide]] salts.<ref name=jhs/>

==Confusion==
Pleurocybella porrigens received this name because of the extravagant form and for being non-gelatinous. Thus, it is quite difficult to confuse, for example with ''Cheimonophyllum'' sin. ''Pleurotus candidissimum'' (inedible),<ref>[Rolf Singer: „Cheimonophyllum candidissimum (Berk. & M.A. Curtis)”, în: „ Sydowia”, vol. IX (1-6), Editura Ferdinand Berger & Söhne G.m.b.H., Viena 1955, p. 417</ref>  ''Crepidotus mollis'' (inedible),<ref>Hans E. Laux: „Der große Pilzführer, Editura Kosmos, Halberstadt 2001,  p. 334-335, {{ISBN|978-3-440-14530-2}}</ref>  ''Panellus mitis'' (inedible)<ref>Hans E. Laux: „Der große Pilzführer, Editura Kosmos, Halberstadt 2001,  p. 192-193, {{ISBN|978-3-440-14530-2}}</ref> or ''Pleurotus cornucopiae'' (edible),<ref>Bruno Cetto: „Der große Pilzführer”, vol. 2, Editura BLV Verlagsgesellschaft, München, Berna, Viena 1980, p. 476-477, {{ISBN|3-405-12081-0}}</ref> ''Pleurotus ostreatus'' var. (white form, very delicious),<ref>I funghi dal vero, vol. 5, Editura Arte Grafiche Saturnia, Trento 1986, p. 418-419, {{ISBN|88-85013-37-6}}</ref> ''Pleurotus pulmonarius'' (edible),<ref>Bruno Cetto: „Der große Pilzführer”, vol. 3, Editura BLV Verlagsgesellschaft, München, Berna, Viena 1980, p. 414-415, {{ISBN|3-405-12124-8}}</ref> but perhaps even with ''Cantharellus cibarius'' var. bicolored (very tasty<ref name=" Bruno Cetto 3.1">Bruno Cetto: „Der große Pilzführer”, vol. 3, Editura BLV Verlagsgesellschaft, München, Berna, Viena 1980, p. 450-451, {{ISBN|3-405-12124-8}}</ref> or ''Craterellus melanoxeros sin. Cantharellus janthinoxanthus'' (very tasty),<ref name=" Bruno Cetto 3.1"/>
